726602f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Rodman Street - North Hempstead Turnpike.]
726602f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Viewing west (views 1,2) across the Flushing meadows toward the Corona dump hills, seen from Rodman Street and North Hempstead Turnpike. In the foreground is Mill Pond and the winding Flushing Creek. This area later became the main exposition center of the New York World's
Fair 1939-40.
Views 2 and 3 are in a northwesterly direction across the marshy meadows fromm Rodman Street and show the Roosevelt Avenue subway "El" under construction in the background.
1925
Views 1,2,3,4
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

726631f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Roosevelt Avenue - Flushing Bay.]
726631f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three views in a southeasterly direction across the north end of the park lying between Roosevelt Avenue and Flushing Bay. This area is being constructed into large automobile parking spaces for visitors to the New York World's Fair 1939-40. In the background is the I. R. T. and B. M. T. subway "g;" on Roosevelt Avenue; in the foregound is Grand Central Parkway (view 2) and on the extreme left (view 3) is Northern Boulevard and Flushing Bay. In the distant background is Flushing.
October 21, 1936

P. L. Sperr

726664f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [New York World's Fair of 1939-40.]
726664f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park ('ueens): The fifty-foot sundial, world's largest, by Paul Manship, at the World's Fair 1939-40. The scolpture depicts the three Fates passing Life's Thread back from Future to Present to Past under the Tree of LLife. In view 2, viewing east across Washington Square, is the heroic figure of George Washington, with the United States
Government Building in the background.
May 29, 1939
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr

726679f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 -[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics Pavilion.]
726679f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Cueens): The pavilion of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russiaw) at the New York Vorlda Fair 1939-40, seen across the Lagoon of Nstions. Atop the tower of marble and porphyry at the entrance to the building is a stainless steel figure, designed by Vyacheslav Andreev, depicts the spirit of bhe Souiet worker. It weighs thirty tons and forms, after the Trylon--the Worldtc Fair theme--the highest spet at the Fair. Architects of the pavilion are Boris N. Iofan and Karo S. Alabian. On the two wings of the puilding are reliefs of Stalin
(left) and Lenin.
May 29, 1939
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
726679f-a.folder: Flushing Meadow Park & New York World's Fair of 1939-40 -[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics Pavilion.], Queens, NY

726702f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - New York World's Fair Administration Building.]
726702f-a.text:
Completed Adminstration Building of the New York World's Fair 1939 which becase ready today (Trday) for occupancy on Monday by a force of 600 employes who are being transferred from the Empire State Building over the weekend. Construction of the Administration Building, at the site in Flushing Meadow, Uueens, was completed in the record time of 124 days. Ihe cost was approximately 1900,Lwu. "This picture is sent to you for publication only and must not be used for advertising or comercial purposes without written permission from New York
World's Pair 1939 Incorporated.'

726661f-b.text:

sign reads: World's FAir Hall of Fame
Presents
The Streets of Paris
Direct from Broadway
Abbott  Oypay
and  Rose
Costello  Lee
View 3 shows the bridge to the gardens on parade and the
British Empire Building (right).
Views 1,2: June 16, 1940
View 3: August 30, 1940
P. L. Sperr

726676f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - [Buildings of foreign governments.]
726676f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (2ueens): Three of the buildings of foreigh governments at the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. View 1 shows the Japanese Pavilion, modeled after an ancient shinto shrine, with its massive overhanging roof and is set in
a setting of oriental gardens and rocky pools.
View 2 shows the Czechoslovakian Building and view 3,
Holland Village.
View 1: June 8, 1940
Views 2,3: June 21, 1940
P. L. Sperr

726672f-c.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - [Industrial exhibits.]
726672f-c.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three of the industrial exhibits at the New York World's Fair 1939-40, situated in the southeast corner of the main exposition center. View 1 shows the DuPont Building, "The Wonder World of Chemistry," the designer of which is Walter Dorwin Teague; view 2, the General Electric Company Building. Voorhees, Walker, Foley and Smith are the architects; view 3, the Petroleum Industry Building, the roof of which is painted blue and is illuminated at night with fluorescent tubes.
June 16, 1940
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

726611f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Grand Central Parkway - 76th Avenue.]
726611f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): A general view northeastward from near Grand Central Parkway and 75th Avenue, showing the grounds of the New York World's Fair 1939-40 under construction. This area later became part of the amusement center; two artificial lakes--Willow Lake and Fountain Lake--were created here.
View 1: April 23, 1936
Views 2,3: February 10, 1937
P. L. Sperr

728262f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Interboro Rapid Transit Carbarn.]
728262f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): A train of old Brooklyn Ash Removal Company cars in the northern portion of the park, before this area was transformed into part of the grounds of the New York World's Fair 1939-40. In the right background are the I. R. T. car barns.
View 2 is toward the Roosevelt Avenue subway and vehicular
bridge over the Flushing River.
View 3 shows the same area being developed for the World's
Fair. Note the I. R. T. car barns.
View 1: September 30, 1935
View 2: October 5, 1935
View 3: October 18, 1936
P. L. Sperr

726604f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Mill Pond.]
726604f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Viewing north across the meadows and Mill Pond, at the eastern extremity of the park,toward a small community clustered around Willow Street and Fowler Avenue, seen from Rodman Street at North Hempstead Turnpike. This area later became part of the main exposition center of the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. The Court of Peace and the Foreign Zone were constructed here.
1925

View 3

726645f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [New York World's Fair grounds.]
726645f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (World's Fair Site). A set of two views, showing the center of what will be eventually the largest park for the Borough of Queens. View No. 1 shows partially the Strongs Causeway Bridge over Flushing Creek, and a portion of Strongs Causeway. This bridge has been replaced with a larger one and the Causeway rebuilt and renamed the Horace Harding Blvd. View number two shows the Corona Dumps and also an old automobile dump. The area in these views has been graded and beautified and is now a part of the World's Fair Site.
1924
View 2:  June 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
726645f-a.folder: Flushing Meadow Park & [New York World's Fair grounds.], Queens, NY

726663f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [New York World's Fair of 1939-40.]
726663f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Shown, in a set of three views, is the monumental George Washingto) by the sculptor James Earle Fraser, and a group of small figures called 'The Moods of Time," by Paul Manship. The .ashington statue stands at the west end of Constitution Mall, is sixty-five feet high ad includes a fifteenfoot base. 'The Moods of Tiwe" depict morning, dav, evening, and night. Seen from right to left they are: morning, night, day, and
evening.
May 29, 1939
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

726678f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): The flags and pavilions of foreign nations at the New York World's Fair 1939-40, seen across the Lagoon of Nations. On the left is the white-towered Romanion House; to the right of it ta the building of the lInfon of Soviet Socialist Republics, with a gigantic figure of a Soeiet worker holding aloft a red star atop of it; on the extreme right is the
Czechoslovakian Pavilion.
View 1: May 29, 1939
View 2: June 8, 1940

726677f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (2ueens): The British (left) and Italian Buildings at the World's Fair of 1939-4O, seen across the Lagoon of Nations in a northeasterly direction. The architects of the British Building are Stanley Hall and Easton and Robertson. The goddess Roma dominates the Italian Pavilion whtch combines classical with modern architecture. A waterfall cascades down the front
of the building.
View 1: May 29, 1939
View 2: June 21, 1940

726673f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - [Industrial exhibits; Communications Building; National Cash Register Company; United States Steel Corporation.]
726673f-b.text:
Flushing Seadow Park (Cueens): Three of the industrial exhibits at the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. View 1 shows the National Cash Register Company Building; view 2, the Communications Building, the architects of which are Francis Keally and Leonard Dean. A mural by Eugene Savage shows an Indian smoke signal and nude muses. Two 150-foot pylons adorn both sides of the entrance. View 3 is the TInited States Steel Corp. Building. It appropriately has its steel framework outside the shell of the structure. The architects are York and Sawyer.
View 1: June 21, 1940
View 2: May 29, 1939
View 3: June 16, 1940
F. L. Sperr
